definitions.definition: to (cause to) divide into two or more parts, especially along a particular line:
examples: The prize was split between Susan and Kate.
The wooden floor had cracked and split in the heat.

definitions.definition: If the people in an organization or group split, or if something splits them, they disagree and form smaller groups:
examples: The childcare issue has split the employers' group.

definitions.definition: If you split the difference, you agree on a number or amount that is exactly in the middle of the difference between two other numbers or amounts.
a long, thin hole in something where it has broken apart:
examples: Rain was getting in through a split in the plastic sheeting.

definitions.definition: a situation in which a group of people is divided into smaller groups because they disagree about something:
examples: There is a widening split between senior managers and the rest of the workforce.

definitions.definition: the action of sitting on the floor with your legs straight out and flat along the floor in opposite directions:
